review.title: How consistent are our discourse annotations? Insights from mapping RST-DT and PDTB annotations
review.abstract: Discourse-annotated corpora are an important resource for the community. However, these corpora are often annotated according to different frameworks, making comparison of the annotations difficult. This is unfortunate, since mapping the existing annotations would result in more (training) data for researchers in automatic discourse relation processing and researchers in linguistics and psycholinguistics. In this article, we present an effort to map two large corpora onto each other: the Penn Discourse Treebank and the Rhetorical Structure Theory Discourse Treebank. We first propose a method for aligning the discourse segments, and then evaluate the observed against the expected mappings for explicit and implicit relations separately. We find that while agreement on explicit relations is reasonable, agreement between the frameworks on implicit relations is astonishingly low. We identify sources of systematic discrepancies between the two annotation schemes; many of the differences in annotation can be traced back to different operationalizations and goals of the PDTB and RST frameworks. We discuss the consequences of these discrepancies for future annotation, and the usability of the mapped data for theoretical studies and the training of automatic discourse relation labellers.

This is regrettable, since mapping the existing annotations would lead to more (educational) data for researchers in the automatic processing of discourse relations and researchers in linguistics and psycholinguistics. In this article, we present the attempt to map two major corporations together: the Penn Discourse Bank and the Rhetorical Structure Discourse Treebank. sections.heading: 5.3 Analysis of annotation for ambiguous connectives
sections.text: Given the discrepancies, which sometimes also relate to different interpretations of specific ambiguous connectors, as discussed in Section 5.1, we examined the agreement on the note of ambiguous connectors in detail. Finally, it is not surprising to achieve a high degree of agreement between the frameworks for labeling relationships with a unique connector, such as that referred to as CONDITIONAL; this could happen automatically. Rather, the value of the manual note is achieved by adding additional information through discambiguity between relationships if the marker is ambiguous (or if a relationship is not explicitly labeled, see Section 5.4 below). To this end, for each connectivity, we have tested whether comments from the two schemes match significantly more than one would expect that the relationship between people is ambiguous (or if a relationship is not explicitly labeled, see Section 5.4 below).

sections.heading: 5.5 Mapping RST annotations onto PDTB annotations for implicit relations
sections.text: Table 5 shows the alignment of implicit relationships from the perspective of the RST. Many cells are colored green, indicating that the annotations for many of the RST relationships have a wide variety of PDTB labels. For RST's BACKGROUND, CIRCUMSTANCE, and COMMENT relationships in particular, the PDTB labels are distributed almost evenly among the most important classes of relationships, suggesting that these RST labels classify relationships according to communicative functions that are not represented in the PDTB annotation Scheme. RST's Causal Relations CONSEQUENCE, REASONS 5, and RESULT6 cards are relatively well associated with the causal relationships of the PDTB. However, other causal RST labels (EVIDENCE and EXPLANATION ARGUMENTATIVES) are often associated with the additive PDTB labels.
